New Module

Data Visualization ‚Äî Data‚ÄëDriven & Real‚ÄëTime

Move beyond tables: dynamic charts, live KPIs, and interactive insights

After you‚Äôve learned to build UI and deploy your app, it‚Äôs time to make your data come alive. This module introduces data‚Äëdriven visualization and real‚Äëtime techniques so you can explore, monitor, and explain your datasets with clarity ‚Äî not just rows and columns.

Why visualizations?

  • See patterns, trends, and anomalies quickly.
  • Tell compelling, decision‚Äëready stories.
  • Support ops with live KPIs and alerts.

What you‚Äôll build

  • Interactive dashboards (time series, bars, scatter).
  • Live charts that auto‚Äërefresh from your database.
  • Cross‚Äëfilters and lightweight drill‚Äëdowns.

Where it fits

  • After deployment & basic UI are in place.
  • When stakeholders need up‚Äëto‚Äëdate views.
  • When tables aren‚Äôt enough for insight.
Choices

Visualization Options (Pick the Right Tool)

From Streamlit built‚Äëins to D3.js ‚Äî trade‚Äëoffs and use‚Äëcases

Streamlit (built‚Äëins)

  • st.line_chart, st.area_chart, st.bar_chart.
  • Fastest path for internal dashboards.
  • Great for time series & KPIs with minimal code.

Altair / Vega‚ÄëLite

  • Declarative charts, interactions, linked selections.
  • Readable JSON grammar; integrates in Streamlit.
  • Balanced power/complexity for analytics apps.

Plotly

  • Rich interactivity (hover, zoom, facets).
  • Good for exploratory dashboards and notebooks.
  • Streamlit support via st.plotly_chart.

D3.js (Data‚ÄëDriven Documents)

  • Web‚Äënative, bespoke visuals (fine control).
  • Higher effort; best for product‚Äëgrade UI.
  • Great for custom interactions/animations.

Start with Streamlit‚Äôs built‚Äëins for speed. Reach for Altair/Plotly when you need richer interactions. Use D3.js when you need complete control in a web app (e.g., custom charts embedded in a product).

Live Data

Real‚ÄëTime Patterns

Make graphs update as your data changes

1) Smart Polling

  • Periodic queries with caching (e.g., ttl on DB calls).
  • Filter by time window or updated_at to fetch only changes.
  • Simple, reliable ‚Äî ideal for Streamlit.

2) Push (WebSockets)

  • Server pushes new points to clients instantly.
  • Requires a small backend (e.g., FastAPI + websockets).
  • Best for high‚Äëfrequency telemetry.

3) DB Notifications

  • Database triggers & NOTIFY/LISTEN to signal updates.
  • Use a worker to relay events to your app.
  • Great for event‚Äëdriven pipelines.

For Streamlit, start with smart polling. It‚Äôs one line to add a cache TTL and friendly on pooled DB connections. Upgrade to push when you need sub‚Äësecond reactions.

Quick Start

Hello, Live Chart (Streamlit + SQL Connection)

Minimal code to plot a 7‚Äëday time series with auto‚Äërefresh

Prereqs: you already have [connections.neon].url in .streamlit/secrets.toml.

import streamlit as st

st.set_page_config(page_title="Live KPI", page_icon="üìà", layout="centered")
st.title("üìà Live KPI ‚Äî Attendance (last 7 days)")

conn = st.connection("neon", type="sql")

# Auto-refresh every 15s via query TTL (smart polling)
df = conn.query(
    """
    SELECT date AS day, COUNT(*) AS checkins
    FROM app.attendance_log
    WHERE date >= CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '7 days'
    GROUP BY day
    ORDER BY day
    """,
    ttl="15s"
)

st.line_chart(df.set_index("day")["checkins"])

This pattern scales to many charts: keep each query focused and cached, and prefer small windows (e.g., 7‚Äì30 days) for fast render and a responsive feel.

Guidelines

UX & Performance Tips

Keep visuals fast, legible, and decision‚Äëready

  • Window and downsample: show recent data; use daily/weekly resampling for long horizons.
  • Cache wisely: add ttl to DB queries (e.g., 15‚Äì60s) to reduce load and jitter.
  • Readable axes & units: date formats, thousands separators, consistent colors/labels.
  • Link filters: time range + metric selector for self‚Äëserve exploration.
  • Non‚Äëblocking updates: avoid tight loops; let Streamlit rerun on interaction and cache in between.
Next

Where we go from here

From MVP charts to interactive, real‚Äëtime dashboards

  • Add metric pickers and date filters (sidebar).
  • Build a multi‚Äëchart dashboard with shared range controls.
  • Introduce alerts (e.g., threshold breaches) and badges.
  • Consider a push channel (WebSockets) for high‚Äëfrequency feeds.
  • For production UI, evaluate a D3.js front‚Äëend for custom visual stories.
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

D3.js ‚Ä¢ Gallery

Most‚ÄëUsed D3 Visuals for Real‚ÄëWorld Data

Pick the right pattern for time‚Äëseries, maps, hierarchies, and dense temporal data

D3.js (Data‚ÄëDriven Documents) gives you low‚Äëlevel control to draw exactly the chart you need in the browser. Below are hand‚Äëpicked, working examples (via Observable) you can embed directly with an

2) World Tour ‚Äî step through locations globally

Ideal for sequences of geolocated events (e.g., shipments, sensor deployments) where you want to tour locations one by one.

3) Seamless Zoomable Map (Tiles)

Use when you need smooth pan/zoom map navigation and plan to overlay custom data later (markers, heatmaps).

4) Hierarchical Edge Bundling ‚Äî workflows & methodologies

Great for showing relationships across a hierarchy (e.g., teams, pipelines, modules) without creating a hairball of lines.

5) Calendar Heatmap ‚Äî daily values across a year

Perfect for daily metrics like commits, energy usage, sales, or attendance ‚Äî quickly spot seasonality and streaks.

6) Hourly Monitoring ‚Äî dense intraday time‚Äëseries

For high‚Äëresolution telemetry (e.g., electricity usage, sensors). Shows daily/weekly rhythms and anomalies.

7) Candlestick ‚Äî revenue/expense or price‚Äëlike series

Good when you have open/high/low/close style aggregates (financials, bid/ask ranges, or summarized operational metrics).

8) Multi‚ÄëLine ‚Äî compare several items over time

Use when multiple related series need to be compared (e.g., KPIs by product/region). Consider small multiples if lines overlap too much.

Visualization ‚Ä¢ Calendar Heatmap

Daily Bank Visits (1 Year) ‚Äî Red‚ÜíWhite‚ÜíGreen Calendar

See low (red) to high (green) traffic by day, laid out like real monthly calendars

This example builds a data‚Äëdriven calendar heatmap for a full year of daily customer visits. Each month appears as a classic Sun‚ÜíSat calendar grid; color encodes visit volume using a Red ‚Üí White ‚Üí Green gradient (low ‚Üí median ‚Üí high). You can tweak the white pivot percentile, cell size, labels, and borders from the sidebar.

Data (CSV)

Place a CSV at /workspaces/learningexamples/bank_visits_2024.csv (or update in the sidebar).

Columns (case‚Äëinsensitive):

  • date ‚Äî e.g., 2024-03-15
  • visits ‚Äî any of: total_visit, total_visits, visits, visit, count, value

View example CSV on GitHub

Run (Codespaces or local)

pip install streamlit altair pandas numpy
streamlit run app.py

Then open the app URL shown in the terminal.

What you‚Äôll see

12 faceted calendars (3√ó4). Hover any day for exact value and date. Grey cells belong to adjacent months.

Preview

Expected Outcome

Monthly calendar heatmaps with tooltips & legend

Copy & Run

app.py ‚Äî Monthly Calendar Heatmaps (Altair + Streamlit)

Paste the code below into app.py and run

# app.py
# Monthly calendar heatmaps (each month separately) with a RED‚ÄìWHITE‚ÄìGREEN gradient.
# Reads: /workspaces/learningexamples/bank_visits_2024.csv
#
# Expected columns (case-insensitive):
#   - date (YYYY-MM-DD)
#   - total_visit (or: total_visits, visits, visit, count, value)

import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import altair as alt

st.set_page_config(page_title="Bank Visits ‚Äî Monthly Calendars", layout="wide")
st.title("Bank Visits ‚Äî Monthly Calendar Heatmaps")

DEFAULT_PATH = "/workspaces/learningexamples/bank_visits_2024.csv"

# ---------------- Sidebar controls ----------------
st.sidebar.header("Settings")
csv_path = st.sidebar.text_input("CSV path", DEFAULT_PATH)
pivot_pct = st.sidebar.slider(
    "White pivot (percentile)", 0.0, 1.0, 0.50, 0.01,
    help="Which percentile maps to white (default 0.50 = median)."
)
missing_color = st.sidebar.color_picker("Outside-month cell color", "#f0f0f0")
cell_border = st.sidebar.checkbox("Show cell borders", value=True)
month_label_style = st.sidebar.selectbox("Month label", ["Full (January)", "Short (Jan)"], index=0)

# Chart sizing (per month)
cell_size = st.sidebar.slider("Cell size (px)", 16, 36, 24)
calendar_width = 7 * cell_size + 30  # per-month chart width
calendar_height = 6 * cell_size + 20 # per-month chart height


@st.cache_data
def load_data(path: str) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df = pd.read_csv(path)
    # tolerant column detection
    cols = {c.lower().strip(): c for c in df.columns}
    date_col = next((cols[c] for c in ["date", "day"] if c in cols), None)
    val_col  = next((cols[c] for c in ["total_visit", "total_visits", "visits", "visit", "count", "value"] if c in cols), None)
    if not date_col or not val_col:
        raise ValueError(f"CSV must have 'date' and a visits column (e.g., 'total_visit'). Found: {list(df.columns)}")
    df = df[[date_col, val_col]].rename(columns={date_col: "date", val_col: "visits"})
    df["date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["date"], errors="coerce")
    df["visits"] = pd.to_numeric(df["visits"], errors="coerce")
    df = df.dropna(subset=["date"]).sort_values("date").reset_index(drop=True)
    return df


def build_year_calendar(raw: pd.DataFrame, year: int) -> pd.DataFrame:
    """
    Build a 6x7 grid for each month (like a wall calendar), aligned to Sunday-start weeks.
    Returns one DataFrame with 12*42 rows (one row per cell).
    """
    # Restrict to the selected year (for merging visits)
    year_data = raw[(raw["date"].dt.year == year)][["date", "visits"]]

    frames = []
    for month in range(1, 13):
        first = pd.Timestamp(year, month, 1)
        last  = (first + pd.offsets.MonthEnd(1))
        # Find the Sunday on or before the 1st
        start_sun = first - pd.Timedelta(days=(first.weekday() + 1) % 7)
        # 6 weeks x 7 days = 42 cells
        grid_dates = pd.date_range(start_sun, periods=42, freq="D")

        dfm = pd.DataFrame({"date": grid_dates})
        dfm["year"] = year
        dfm["month_num"] = month
        dfm["in_month"] = dfm["date"].dt.month.eq(month)
        # day-of-week (Sun=0 ... Sat=6)
        dfm["dow"] = ((dfm["date"].dt.weekday + 1) % 7).astype(int)
        # week index within the calendar grid (0..5)
        dfm["wom"] = ((dfm["date"] - start_sun).dt.days // 7).astype(int)
        # day label
        dfm["day"] = dfm["date"].dt.day.where(dfm["in_month"], other=None)

        # month labels
        if month_label_style.startswith("Full"):
            dfm["month_name"] = first.strftime("%B")
        else:
            dfm["month_name"] = first.strftime("%b")

        # Merge visits for actual dates (outside-month cells remain NaN)
        dfm = dfm.merge(year_data, on="date", how="left")
        frames.append(dfm)

    cal = pd.concat(frames, ignore_index=True)

    # Nice labels
    dow_names = ["Sun", "Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat"]
    cal["dow_name"] = cal["dow"].map({i:n for i, n in enumerate(dow_names)})

    return cal


# ------- Load & prepare data -------
try:
    raw = load_data(csv_path)
except Exception as e:
    st.error(f"Failed to read CSV: {e}")
    st.stop()

years = sorted(raw["date"].dt.year.unique().tolist())
year = st.sidebar.selectbox("Year", years, index=(0 if len(years) == 1 else len(years)-1))

cal = build_year_calendar(raw, year)

# Compute gradient stops from this year's *available* visit values
vals = cal.loc[cal["in_month"] & cal["visits"].notna(), "visits"].to_numpy()
if vals.size == 0:
    st.warning(f"No visit data for {year}.")
    st.stop()

vmin = float(np.nanmin(vals))
vmax = float(np.nanmax(vals))
vpivot = float(np.quantile(vals, pivot_pct))

# Color scale: LOW ‚Üí MID ‚Üí HIGH  =>  Red ‚Üí White ‚Üí Green
color_scale = alt.Scale(
    domain=[vmin, vpivot, vmax],
    range=["#d73027", "#ffffff", "#1a9850"],
    clamp=True,
)

# Axis domains (keep consistent across facets)
dow_order = ["Sun", "Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat"]
wom_order = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
month_order_full  = ["January","February","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","October","November","December"]
month_order_short = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"]
facet_order = month_order_full if month_label_style.startswith("Full") else month_order_short

# Base layer: background cells (outside-month shaded; inside-month white)
base = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .mark_rect(stroke="#E0E0E0" if cell_border else None, strokeWidth=0.5)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N",
                sort=dow_order,
                axis=alt.Axis(title=None, labelAngle=0, labelPadding=6)),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O",
                sort=wom_order,
                axis=alt.Axis(title=None, ticks=False, labels=False)),
        color=alt.condition(
            "datum.in_month",
            alt.value("#FFFFFF"),
            alt.value(missing_color),
        ),
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

# Visits layer: color only the in-month cells with data
visits_layer = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .transform_filter("datum.in_month && isValid(datum.visits)")
    .mark_rect(stroke="#E0E0E0" if cell_border else None, strokeWidth=0.5)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N", sort=dow_order, axis=None),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O", sort=wom_order, axis=None),
        color=alt.Color("visits:Q", scale=color_scale,
                        legend=alt.Legend(title="Visits", gradientLength=120)),
        tooltip=[
            alt.Tooltip("date:T", title="Date"),
            alt.Tooltip("visits:Q", title="Visits", format=",.0f"),
        ],
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

# Day numbers
day_text = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .mark_text(baseline="middle", align="center", dy=0, fontSize=11)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N", sort=dow_order, axis=None),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O", sort=wom_order, axis=None),
        text=alt.condition("datum.in_month", "day:Q", alt.value("")),
        color=alt.condition("datum.in_month", alt.value("#333333"), alt.value("#999999")),
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

# Compose per-month charts and facet (3 columns x 4 rows)
cal_chart = alt.layer(base, visits_layer, day_text).facet(
    facet=alt.Facet("month_name:N", sort=facet_order, title=None),
    columns=3,
)

# ---------------- Layout ----------------
left, right = st.columns([4, 1], gap="large")

with left:
    st.subheader(f"Calendars ‚Äî {year}")
    st.altair_chart(cal_chart, use_container_width=True)

with right:
    st.subheader("Scale")
    st.markdown(
        f"""
**Gradient:**
- **Red** = min (‚âà **{vmin:,.0f}**)
- **White** = {pivot_pct:.0%} percentile (‚âà **{vpivot:,.0f}**)
- **Green** = max (‚âà **{vmax:,.0f}**)

**Notes**
- Each panel is a true month calendar (Sun‚ÄìSat columns, up to 6 weeks).
- Grey cells belong to adjacent months.
        """
    )

st.divider()
with st.expander("Show underlying calendar data (this year)"):
    st.dataframe(
        cal[["date", "month_name", "in_month", "day", "visits"]]
        .sort_values(["date"]),
        use_container_width=True,
    )
Helpful

Usage Tips

Make the calendar read clearly and run fast

  • CSV path: if your file isn‚Äôt in /workspaces/learningexamples/, change the path from the sidebar.
  • White pivot: 50% (median) by default. Move the slider to shift what counts as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù.
  • Missing days: days with no value inside the month render as white with a day number; outside‚Äëmonth cells use the grey swatch from the color picker.
  • Performance: one year (‚âà365 values) is tiny ‚Äî Altair renders quickly. For multiple years, keep the facet to 12 panels per view.
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: Statistics for Visualization ‚Ä¢ Make Your Charts Truthful & Useful

content.body_md:
Module ‚Ä¢ Foundations

Statistics for Data Visualization

Use the right summaries to scale axes, color ranges, and highlight signal (not noise)

Great visuals depend on simple, robust statistics. Min/Max, Mean/Median, Percentiles, Std‚Äëdev and a few transformations (normalization, z‚Äëscores, rolling averages) determine how your charts scale, how colors map to values, and how outliers are treated. Get these right and your visuals become truthful, legible, and decision‚Äëready.

Why stats matter

  • Scaling: choose axis and color ranges (e.g., P5‚ÄìP95) to avoid skew.
  • Comparability: normalize (0‚Äì1) or z‚Äëscore to compare across metrics.
  • Signal vs noise: rolling averages reduce jitter; outlier rules prevent distortion.

At a glance

  • Min/Max: bounds; sensitive to outliers.
  • Median: robust central tendency.
  • Percentiles (P10/P90): robust range for color/axes.
  • Std‚Äëdev: variability; z‚Äëscores for outliers.

Apply to visuals

  • Heatmaps: color domain = [P10, P50, P90].
  • Time‚Äëseries: show line + rolling mean + highlight z‚Äëoutliers.
  • Distributions: Freedman‚ÄëDiaconis bins for histograms.
Fix applied: removed the unsupported Altair argument disabled=... from tooltips and replaced it with a safe, conditional tooltip list (works on Altair v5). This resolves the SchemaValidationError: Tooltip has no parameter named 'disabled'.
Reference

Core statistics & how to use them in charts

Pick the right summary for the job

  • Min / Max ‚Äî absolute bounds. Good for full context, but don‚Äôt use alone to scale color/axis when outliers exist.
  • Mean & Std‚Äëdev ‚Äî average & variability. Use z‚Äëscores to flag points far from the mean (e.g., |z| ‚â• 3).
  • Median & Percentiles (P10, P25, P50, P75, P90) ‚Äî robust against skew. Use quantile clipping (e.g., P5‚ÄìP95) for axis/color limits.
  • IQR (P75‚ÄìP25) ‚Äî robust spread. Box plots and Freedman‚ÄëDiaconis bin widths rely on IQR.
  • Rolling averages ‚Äî smooth noise in time‚Äëseries; pick windows (7, 14, 30 days) based on cadence.
  • Normalization ‚Äî MinMax (0‚Äì1) to compare metrics on a common scale; Z‚Äëscore to center by mean/variance.
Hands‚Äëon

Streamlit: stats ‚Üí visuals (line + histogram + box plot)

Upload a CSV or use a demo series; robust scaling, outliers, rolling

What it does: loads a CSV, picks a date column and a numeric metric, computes min/max/mean/median/percentiles, offers robust range (P5‚ÄìP95), normalization, z‚Äëscore outlier highlighting, rolling mean, and renders three visuals.

# streamlit_stats_viz.py  (Altair v5‚Äëfriendly; no unsupported tooltip args)
import io
from typing import Optional

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import altair as alt
import streamlit as st

st.set_page_config(page_title="Statistics for Visualization", page_icon="üìä", layout="wide")
st.title("üìä Statistics for Visualization ‚Äî Practical Demo")

# ---------------- Demo / Data load ----------------
@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def demo_timeseries(n=365, seed=42) -> pd.DataFrame:
    rng = np.random.default_rng(seed)
    dates = pd.date_range("2024-01-01", periods=n, freq="D")
    # seasonal + noise + a few spikes
    x = np.arange(n)
    val = 100 + 15*np.sin(x/12) + 8*np.cos(x/25) + rng.normal(0, 4, n)
    spikes = rng.choice(n, size=5, replace=False)
    val[spikes] += rng.normal(25, 6, len(spikes))
    return pd.DataFrame({"Date": dates, "Value": val})

@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def read_csv_safely(file) -> Optional[pd.DataFrame]:
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(file)
        # parse common datetime columns
        for c in df.columns:
            if str(c).lower() in ("date","time","datetime","timestamp"):
                df[c] = pd.to_datetime(df[c], errors="coerce")
        return df
    except Exception as e:
        st.error(f"Failed to read CSV: {e}")
        return None

with st.sidebar:
    st.header("Data")
    up = st.file_uploader("Upload CSV", type=["csv"])
    if up is not None:
        df_raw = read_csv_safely(up)
        source = "Uploaded CSV"
    else:
        df_raw = demo_timeseries()
        source = "Demo series (synthetic)"

    if df_raw is None or df_raw.empty:
        st.stop()

    st.caption(f"Source: **{source}**  ‚Ä¢  Rows: **{len(df_raw):,}**  ‚Ä¢  Cols: **{len(df_raw.columns)}**")

    dt_cols = [c for c in df_raw.columns if pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df_raw[c])]
    date_col = st.selectbox("Date column (optional)", [""] + dt_cols, index=(1 if dt_cols else 0))

    num_cols = df_raw.select_dtypes(include="number").columns.tolist()
    if not num_cols:
        st.warning("No numeric columns detected.")
        st.stop()
    metric = st.selectbox("Numeric column", num_cols, index=0)

    st.header("Scaling & Filters")
    robust = st.checkbox("Use robust range (P5‚ÄìP95) for axis/color", value=True)
    roll = st.slider("Rolling mean window", 1, 60, 7, help="Applied on the line chart")
    norm = st.selectbox("Normalize", ["None","MinMax (0‚Äì1)","Z-score"], index=0)
    z_thresh = st.slider("Outlier |z|-threshold", 2.0, 5.0, 3.0, 0.5)

# Prepare DataFrame
df = df_raw.copy()
if date_col != "":
    df = df.dropna(subset=[date_col]).sort_values(date_col)
else:
    df = df.reset_index().rename(columns={"index":"Index"})
    date_col = "Index"

# Numeric series
s = pd.to_numeric(df[metric], errors="coerce").dropna()
df = df.loc[s.index].copy()
df["y"] = s.values

# Summary stats
desc = df["y"].describe(percentiles=[.05,.10,.25,.50,.75,.90,.95]).to_frame(name="value")
ymin, ymax = float(desc.loc["min","value"]), float(desc.loc["max","value"])
mu, sd = float(desc.loc["mean","value"]), float(df["y"].std(ddof=1))
p10, p50, p90 = (float(desc.loc["10%","value"]), float(desc.loc["50%","value"]), float(desc.loc["90%","value"]))
p5, p25, p75, p95 = (float(desc.loc["5%","value"]), float(desc.loc["25%","value"]),
                     float(desc.loc["75%","value"]), float(desc.loc["95%","value"]))

# Normalization for plotting
y_plot = df["y"].copy()
if norm == "MinMax (0‚Äì1)":
    lo, hi = y_plot.min(), y_plot.max()
    y_plot = (y_plot - lo) / (hi - lo) if hi > lo else y_plot*0
elif norm == "Z-score":
    y_plot = (y_plot - mu) / sd if sd > 0 else y_plot*0
df["y_plot"] = y_plot

# Z-score outliers on RAW values
df["is_outlier"] = (abs((df["y"] - mu) / sd) >= z_thresh) if sd > 0 else False

# Rolling mean (on plotted series for visual coherence)
w = max(1, int(roll))
df["roll"] = df["y_plot"].rolling(w, min_periods=1).mean()

# Robust axis range (for reporting)
lo_rep, hi_rep = (p5, p95) if robust else (ymin, ymax)

# ---------------- KPIs ----------------
k1,k2,k3,k4,k5,k6 = st.columns(6)
k1.metric("Min", f"{ymin:,.2f}")
k2.metric("P10 / Median / P90", f"{p10:,.2f} / {p50:,.2f} / {p90:,.2f}")
k3.metric("Max", f"{ymax:,.2f}")
k4.metric("Mean", f"{mu:,.2f}")
k5.metric("Std‚Äëdev", f"{sd:,.2f}")
k6.metric(f"Outliers (|z| ‚â• {z_thresh:.1f})", f"{int(df['is_outlier'].sum()):,}")

# ---------------- Charts ----------------
left, right = st.columns([2,1], gap="large")

# Build a safe tooltip list (Altair v5 ‚Äî no 'disabled' parameter)
is_time = pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[date_col])
if is_time:
    tooltips = [alt.Tooltip(f"{date_col}:T", title="Date", format="%Y-%m-%d"),
                alt.Tooltip("y:Q", title=metric, format=",.2f")]
    x_enc = alt.X(f"{date_col}:T", title=None)
else:
    tooltips = [alt.Tooltip(f"{date_col}:Q", title="Index"),
                alt.Tooltip("y:Q", title=metric, format=",.2f")]
    x_enc = alt.X(f"{date_col}:Q", title=None)

with left:
    st.subheader("Time series")
    base = alt.Chart(df).encode(x=x_enc)

    line = base.mark_line().encode(
        y=alt.Y("y_plot:Q", title=f"{metric} ({'norm' if norm!='None' else 'raw'})"),
        tooltip=tooltips
    )

    roll_line = base.mark_line(strokeDash=[6,4]).encode(
        y="roll:Q",
        tooltip=tooltips
    )

    points = base.mark_circle(size=64, color="#d62728").encode(
        y="y_plot:Q",
        tooltip=tooltips
    ).transform_filter("datum.is_outlier == true")

    st.altair_chart((line + roll_line + points).interactive(), use_container_width=True)

    st.subheader("Histogram")
    # Freedman‚ÄìDiaconis bins (fallback to 30)
    iqr = p75 - p25
    n = len(df)
    width = 2 * iqr * (n ** (-1/3)) if iqr > 0 else None
    maxbins = int(np.clip((ymax - ymin)/width, 8, 80)) if width and width > 0 else 30
    hist = alt.Chart(df).mark_bar().encode(
        x=alt.X("y:Q", bin=alt.Bin(maxbins=maxbins), title=metric),
        y=alt.Y("count():Q", title="Count"),
        tooltip=[alt.Tooltip("count():Q", title="Count")]
    )
    st.altair_chart(hist, use_container_width=True)

with right:
    st.subheader("Box plot")
    box = alt.Chart(df).mark_boxplot(size=60).encode(y=alt.Y("y:Q", title=metric))
    st.altair_chart(box, use_container_width=True)

    st.subheader("Axis / Color suggestion")
    st.code(f"Use {'robust' if robust else 'full'} range: [{lo_rep:,.2f}, {hi_rep:,.2f}]\n"
            "Heatmaps: map colors via [P10, P50, P90] or similar.", language="text")

st.subheader("Outliers")
st.caption("Rows flagged by |z| ‚â• threshold (based on raw values).")
out = df.loc[df["is_outlier"], [date_col, "y"]].rename(columns={date_col:"Date", "y":metric})
st.dataframe(out, use_container_width=True)

Run it

pip install streamlit altair pandas numpy
streamlit run streamlit_stats_viz.py
Recipes

Practical recipes that improve charts

Small changes that make a big difference

  • Heatmap color domain: use [P10, P50, P90] (or P5/P50/P95) instead of [min, mean, max] to avoid outlier domination.
  • Axis limits: clip to [P5, P95] and annotate the clipping rule; retain tooltips for exact values.
  • Rolling overlays: on time‚Äëseries, overlay a 7‚Äë or 14‚Äëday rolling mean to reveal the signal trend.
  • Outlier dots: mark |z|‚â•3 points as red circles on the line; don‚Äôt scale axes to accommodate them.
  • Bins: pick bins with Freedman‚ÄëDiaconis (automatic) or provide a simple slider (8‚Äì80) for analyst control.
  • Compare metrics: MinMax normalize to 0‚Äì1 and plot together; use a secondary scale only when absolutely necessary.

lessons.title: Different Statistical Views of Daily Data

content.body_md:
Visualization ‚Ä¢ Calendars

Five Calendar Views ‚Äî Same Data, Different Statistics

Switch statistical lenses to answer different questions from daily data

1) Raw (P10‚ÄìP50‚ÄìP90)

Absolute values with a robust color domain. Good for overall scale and extremes without letting outliers dominate.

2) Month‚ÄëRelative % of Max

Each month normalized to its own max (0‚Äì1). Great for seeing relative peaks within that month (seasonality removed).

3) Robust Z (Median & MAD)

Deviations from the yearly median scaled by MAD (outlier‚Äëresistant). Symmetric red‚Üîgreen for ‚Äúunusually low/high‚Äù days.

4) 7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean

Smooths noise to reveal weekly trends. Use when daily volatility hides sustained increases/decreases.

5) Deviation vs Day‚Äëof‚ÄëWeek Baseline

Subtracts a DOW baseline (median Monday, Tuesday, ‚Ä¶). Shows how a day performed vs its typical weekday.

Copy the app below to your repo and run it. Use the View selector in the sidebar to switch between the five statistical calendars.

Copy & Run

app_calendar_5_views.py ‚Äî Streamlit + Altair

Faceted (3√ó4) monthly calendars with multiple statistical encodings

# app_calendar_5_views.py
# Five statistical calendar views of daily data (red ‚Üí white ‚Üí green)
# Default CSV: /workspaces/learningexamples/bank_visits_2024.csv
# Columns (case-insensitive): date, total_visit/total_visits/visits/visit/count/value

import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import altair as alt

st.set_page_config(page_title="Calendar Heatmaps ‚Äî 5 Statistical Views", layout="wide")
st.title("üìÖ Calendar Heatmaps ‚Äî Five Statistical Views")

DEFAULT_PATH = "/workspaces/learningexamples/bank_visits_2024.csv"

# ---------------- Sidebar ----------------
st.sidebar.header("Data & View")
csv_path = st.sidebar.text_input("CSV path", DEFAULT_PATH)
view = st.sidebar.selectbox(
    "Calendar view",
    [
        "Raw (P10‚ÄìP50‚ÄìP90)",
        "Month‚ÄëRelative % of Max (0‚Äì1)",
        "Robust Z (Median & MAD)",
        "7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean",
        "Deviation vs Day‚Äëof‚ÄëWeek Baseline",
    ],
    index=0
)

# Shared appearance
missing_color = st.sidebar.color_picker("Outside‚Äëmonth cell color", "#BDBDBD")
cell_border = st.sidebar.checkbox("Show cell borders", value=True)
month_label_style = st.sidebar.selectbox("Month label", ["Full (January)", "Short (Jan)"], index=0)
cell_size = st.sidebar.slider("Cell size (px)", 16, 36, 24)
calendar_width  = 7 * cell_size + 30
calendar_height = 6 * cell_size + 20

# View‚Äëspecific controls
st.sidebar.header("Statistics")
pivot_pct = None
limit = None
roll_window = None
dow_stat = None

if view in ["Raw (P10‚ÄìP50‚ÄìP90)", "7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean"]:
    pivot_pct = st.sidebar.slider("White pivot (percentile)", 0.0, 1.0, 0.50, 0.01)
if view == "Robust Z (Median & MAD)":
    limit = st.sidebar.slider("Diverging limit (¬±)", 1.0, 6.0, 3.0, 0.5, help="Clamps color domain to [‚àíL, 0, +L].")
if view == "7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean":
    roll_window = st.sidebar.slider("Rolling window (days)", 3, 30, 7, 1)
if view == "Deviation vs Day‚Äëof‚ÄëWeek Baseline":
    dow_stat = st.sidebar.selectbox("Baseline statistic", ["Median", "Mean"], index=0)
    limit = st.sidebar.slider("Diverging limit (¬±)", 5.0, 200.0, 50.0, 5.0,
                              help="Clamps color domain for deviation from DOW baseline.")

# ---------------- Data Load ----------------
@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def load_csv(path: str) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df = pd.read_csv(path)
    cols = {c.lower().strip(): c for c in df.columns}
    date_col = next((cols[c] for c in ["date","day"] if c in cols), None)
    val_col  = next((cols[c] for c in ["total_visit","total_visits","visits","visit","count","value"] if c in cols), None)
    if not date_col or not val_col:
        raise ValueError("CSV must have 'date' and a visits column (e.g., 'total_visit').")
    df = df[[date_col, val_col]].rename(columns={date_col: "date", val_col: "visits"})
    df["date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["date"], errors="coerce")
    df["visits"] = pd.to_numeric(df["visits"], errors="coerce")
    df = df.dropna(subset=["date"]).sort_values("date").reset_index(drop=True)
    return df

try:
    raw = load_csv(csv_path)
except Exception as e:
    st.error(f"Failed to read CSV: {e}")
    st.stop()

years = sorted(raw["date"].dt.year.unique().tolist())
year  = st.sidebar.selectbox("Year", years, index=(0 if len(years)==1 else len(years)-1))
year_data = raw[raw["date"].dt.year == year][["date","visits"]].copy()
if year_data.empty:
    st.warning(f"No data for {year}.")
    st.stop()

# ---------------- Calendar Grid Builder ----------------
def build_year_calendar(year_df: pd.DataFrame, year: int) -> pd.DataFrame:
    frames = []
    for month in range(1, 13):
        first = pd.Timestamp(year, month, 1)
        start_sun = first - pd.Timedelta(days=(first.weekday() + 1) % 7)
        grid_dates = pd.date_range(start_sun, periods=42, freq="D")
        dfm = pd.DataFrame({"date": grid_dates})
        dfm["month_num"] = month
        dfm["in_month"]  = dfm["date"].dt.month.eq(month)
        dfm["dow"] = ((dfm["date"].dt.weekday + 1) % 7).astype(int)  # Sun=0
        dfm["wom"] = ((dfm["date"] - start_sun).dt.days // 7).astype(int)
        dfm["day"] = dfm["date"].dt.day.where(dfm["in_month"], other=None)
        dfm["month_name"] = first.strftime("%B") if month_label_style.startswith("Full") else first.strftime("%b")
        frames.append(dfm)
    cal = pd.concat(frames, ignore_index=True)
    cal = cal.merge(year_df, on="date", how="left")  # adds 'visits'
    dow_names = ["Sun","Mon","Tue","Wed","Thu","Fri","Sat"]
    cal["dow_name"] = cal["dow"].map(dict(enumerate(dow_names)))
    return cal

cal = build_year_calendar(year_data, year)

# ---------------- Value Encoding per View ----------------
legend_title = ""
color_scale = None

def seq_scale(lo, mid, hi):
    return alt.Scale(domain=[float(lo), float(mid), float(hi)],
                     range=["#d73027","#ffffff","#1a9850"], clamp=True)

def div_scale(limit):
    L = float(limit)
    return alt.Scale(domain=[-L, 0.0, +L],
                     range=["#d73027","#ffffff","#1a9850"], clamp=True)

if view == "Raw (P10‚ÄìP50‚ÄìP90)":
    vals = cal.loc[cal["in_month"] & cal["visits"].notna(), "visits"].to_numpy()
    p10 = np.quantile(vals, 0.10) if vals.size else 0
    p50 = np.quantile(vals, float(pivot_pct)) if vals.size else 0  # pivot can be any quantile; default 0.50
    p90 = np.quantile(vals, 0.90) if vals.size else 1
    cal["value"] = cal["visits"]
    legend_title = "Visits"
    color_scale = seq_scale(p10, p50, p90)

elif view == "Month‚ÄëRelative % of Max (0‚Äì1)":
    # per-month normalization (within this year)
    month_max = year_data.assign(month=year_data["date"].dt.month) \
                         .groupby("month")["visits"].max()
    cal = cal.join(month_max, on=cal["month_num"], rsuffix="_mmax")
    denom = cal["visits_mmax"].replace({0: np.nan})
    cal["value"] = (cal["visits"] / denom).clip(0, 1)
    cal.loc[denom.isna(), "value"] = np.nan  # if month had no data
    cal = cal.drop(columns=["visits_mmax"])
    legend_title = "% of month max"
    color_scale = seq_scale(0.0, 0.5, 1.0)

elif view == "Robust Z (Median & MAD)":
    # robust z = 0.6745 * (x - median) / MAD
    x = year_data["visits"].to_numpy()
    med = float(np.median(x))
    mad = float(np.median(np.abs(x - med)))
    if mad == 0:
        rz = (year_data["visits"] - med) * 0.0
    else:
        rz = 0.6745 * (year_data["visits"] - med) / mad
    year_rz = year_data.assign(value=rz)[["date","value"]]
    cal = cal.drop(columns=["value"], errors="ignore").merge(year_rz, on="date", how="left")
    legend_title = "Robust z"
    color_scale = div_scale(limit)

elif view == "7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean":
    # trailing centered=False rolling mean on complete year series
    ydf = year_data.sort_values("date").copy()
    ydf["value"] = ydf["visits"].rolling(int(roll_window), min_periods=1).mean()
    cal = cal.drop(columns=["value"], errors="ignore").merge(ydf[["date","value"]], on="date", how="left")
    vals = cal.loc[cal["in_month"] & cal["value"].notna(), "value"].to_numpy()
    p10 = np.quantile(vals, 0.10) if vals.size else 0
    p50 = np.quantile(vals, float(pivot_pct)) if vals.size else 0
    p90 = np.quantile(vals, 0.90) if vals.size else 1
    legend_title = f"{int(roll_window)}‚Äëday mean"
    color_scale = seq_scale(p10, p50, p90)

else:  # Deviation vs DOW Baseline
    ydf = year_data.assign(dow=((year_data["date"].dt.weekday + 1) % 7))
    if dow_stat == "Median":
        base = ydf.groupby("dow")["visits"].median()
    else:
        base = ydf.groupby("dow")["visits"].mean()
    cal = cal.join(base, on="dow", rsuffix="_base")
    cal["value"] = cal["visits"] - cal["visits_base"]
    cal = cal.drop(columns=["visits_base"])
    legend_title = f"Œî vs {dow_stat} DOW"
    color_scale = div_scale(limit)

# ---------------- Chart ----------------
dow_order = ["Sun","Mon","Tue","Wed","Thu","Fri","Sat"]
wom_order = [0,1,2,3,4,5]
month_full  = ["January","February","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","October","November","December"]
month_short = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"]
facet_order = month_full if month_label_style.startswith("Full") else month_short

base = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .mark_rect(stroke="#E0E0E0" if cell_border else None, strokeWidth=0.5)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N", sort=dow_order, axis=alt.Axis(title=None, labelAngle=0, labelPadding=6)),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O",      sort=wom_order, axis=alt.Axis(title=None, ticks=False, labels=False)),
        color=alt.condition("datum.in_month", alt.value("#FFFFFF"), alt.value(missing_color)),
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

vals_layer = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .transform_filter("datum.in_month && isValid(datum.value)")
    .mark_rect(stroke="#E0E0E0" if cell_border else None, strokeWidth=0.5)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N", sort=dow_order, axis=None),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O", sort=wom_order, axis=None),
        color=alt.Color("value:Q", scale=color_scale, legend=alt.Legend(title=legend_title, gradientLength=120)),
        tooltip=[
            alt.Tooltip("date:T",   title="Date"),
            alt.Tooltip("visits:Q", title="Visits", format=",.0f"),
            alt.Tooltip("value:Q",  title=legend_title)
        ],
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

day_text = (
    alt.Chart(cal)
    .mark_text(baseline="middle", align="center", dy=0, fontSize=11)
    .encode(
        x=alt.X("dow_name:N", sort=dow_order, axis=None),
        y=alt.Y("wom:O", sort=wom_order, axis=None),
        text=alt.condition("datum.in_month", "day:Q", alt.value("")),
        color=alt.condition("datum.in_month", alt.value("#333333"), alt.value("#999999")),
    )
    .properties(width=calendar_width, height=calendar_height)
)

chart = alt.layer(base, vals_layer, day_text).facet(
    facet=alt.Facet("month_name:N", sort=facet_order, title=None),
    columns=3
)

# ---------------- Layout ----------------
left, right = st.columns([4,1], gap="large")
with left:
    st.subheader(f"Calendars ‚Äî {year}")
    st.caption(f"View: **{view}**")
    st.altair_chart(chart, use_container_width=True)

with right:
    st.subheader("Legend / Notes")
    if view in ["Raw (P10‚ÄìP50‚ÄìP90)", "7‚ÄëDay Rolling Mean"]:
        st.markdown(f"- Red ‚Üí low (‚âà P10)\n- White ‚Üí {int(pivot_pct*100)}th percentile\n- Green ‚Üí high (‚âà P90)")
    elif view == "Month‚ÄëRelative % of Max (0‚Äì1)":
        st.markdown("- Red ‚Üí 0 (low for that month)\n- White ‚Üí 0.5\n- Green ‚Üí 1.0 (month peak)")
    elif view == "Robust Z (Median & MAD)":
        st.markdown(f"- Diverging domain: ¬±{limit}\n- Red ‚Üí below median ¬∑ Green ‚Üí above median")
    else:
        st.markdown(f"- Œî vs {dow_stat} DOW baseline\n- Diverging domain: ¬±{limit}")

st.divider()
with st.expander("Show underlying data (this year)"):
    st.dataframe(cal[["date","month_name","in_month","day","visits","value"]].sort_values("date"),
                 use_container_width=True)

Run it

pip install streamlit altair pandas numpy
streamlit run app_calendar_5_views.py
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: D3.js Once ‚Ä¢ Always Fresh via SQL

content.body_md:
D3.js ‚Ä¢ SQL ‚Ä¢ Ops

Build Once, Update Forever ‚Äî D3.js fed by SQL

Your D3 chart is a final outcome: one-time build; data changes flow from SQL to the same chart automatically.

The key idea: separate the visualization from the data pipeline. You compile and deploy your D3.js chart once (static assets), and you expose data from SQL via a stable JSON/CSV endpoint. As data changes, the endpoint returns fresh values ‚Äî the chart updates on load (or on a lightweight timer) without rebuilding the D3 code.

Workflow

One‚ÄëTime Build ‚Ä¢ Continuous Data Updates

Two tracks: build (once) and data (forever)

A) One‚Äëtime build One‚Äëtime
Design & Develop
D3 chart (axes, scales, tooltips, legend)
‚Üí
Static Assets
index.html ‚Ä¢ bundle.js ‚Ä¢ styles.css
‚Üí
Host
Static hosting / CDN (e.g., GitHub Pages, Netlify, S3+CloudFront)
B) Continuous data path Recurring
Data Entry
App forms ‚Ä¢ CSV uploads ‚Ä¢ Integrations
‚Üí
SQL Database
Postgres/Neon ‚Ä¢ SQLite ‚Ä¢ (your choice)
‚Üí
Transform Layer
Views / Materialized Views ‚Ä¢ Validation
‚Üí
API / Feed
JSON / CSV endpoint with stable schema
‚Üí
D3 Fetch
Chart reads endpoint at runtime
Build track: you only redo this if you change visual design or logic (new chart type, fields, interactivity).
Data track: runs forever. New rows enter SQL ‚Üí transformed view ‚Üí endpoint ‚Üí chart loads fresh data.
Lifecycle

Update Loop ‚Äî from new row to visible change

What happens after you insert new data

C) Data ‚Üí Chart propagation Recurring
Insert/Update
New facts written to raw tables
‚Üí
Refresh
View recompute / MatView refresh (cron, trigger, webhook)
‚Üí
Cache Policy
API TTL / CDN TTL (invalidate or let expire)
‚Üí
Fetch in Browser
On load or timed refresh (e.g., every 5‚Äì15 min)
‚Üí
Re‚Äërender
D3 scales update ‚Ä¢ marks transition
No redeploy needed: the chart file does not change. Only the data response changes.
Observability: log refresh jobs, expose last_updated in your endpoint, surface it in the chart footer.
Architecture

Who owns what? (Separation of concerns)

Keep each responsibility focused for reliability

D) Responsibilities map
Data Producers
Create/ingest records; ensure data quality at source
‚Üí
Data Modelers
SQL views/matviews; schema versioning; business logic
‚Üí
API / Platform
Stable endpoints; auth; caching; pagination
‚Üí
D3 Visualization
Rendering logic; scales; accessibility; UX
‚Üí
Ops / SRE
Monitoring, alerts, uptime, budgets
  • Stable contract: the endpoint is a contract ‚Äî fields, types, units. Backward‚Äëcompatible changes keep charts stable.
  • Versioning: if you must break the contract, create /v2 (charts adopt it when ready).
  • Performance: pre‚Äëaggregate in SQL; send only what the chart needs (filters, date windows).
Deployment

Minimal topology for sustainable updates

Decouple static front‚Äëend from live data back‚Äëend

E) Topology
Static Hosting (CDN)
D3 assets cached globally ‚Ä¢ cheap & fast
‚áÑ
API Gateway
HTTPS JSON/CSV ‚Ä¢ auth ‚Ä¢ rate limits ‚Ä¢ TTL
‚Üí
App/Service
Transforms & serves DB results (or direct SQL read‚Äëonly)
‚Üí
SQL Database
Tables ‚Ä¢ Views/MatViews ‚Ä¢ Indexes ‚Ä¢ Jobs
  • Security: keep write access behind the API; D3 reads public, read‚Äëonly data.
  • Latency: cache at the API and CDN; expose ttl policy; support query params for date range.
Checklist

‚ÄúBuild once‚Äù sustainability checklist

No code ‚Äî just operating rules

  • ‚úîÔ∏è Endpoint contract: document field names, units, null policy, sort order.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Include metadata: last_updated, source, window, version.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Pre‚Äëaggregate: give D3 chart exactly the granularity it needs.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Refresh strategy: cron for matviews; webhook on ingest; set CDN/API TTLs.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Backfill safe: re‚Äëruns shouldn‚Äôt break; idempotent loaders; primary keys + constraints.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Observability: logs, error budgets, alerts on stale data or endpoint errors.
  • ‚úîÔ∏è A11y & UX: fallback text for empty data; show ‚Äúas of‚Äù timestamp; keyboard navigation.
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: D3 Module ‚Äî Conclusion & Where to Use It

content.body_md:
Module ‚Ä¢ Conclusion

D3.js: Build Once, Tell Better Stories with Your Data

From statistics‚Äëfirst thinking to sustainable, auto‚Äëupdating visuals

In this module you learned to treat visualization as a pipeline, not a one‚Äëoff graphic. You:

  • Applied robust statistics (percentiles, rolling means, baseline comparisons) to make honest scales and color domains.
  • Built calendar heatmaps in multiple statistical ‚Äúviews‚Äù to answer different business questions from the same data.
  • Separated concerns: SQL ‚Üí API/feed ‚Üí D3, so charts are compiled once and update themselves as new data arrives.

The result is a sustainable system: D3 handles custom, high‚Äëfidelity visuals, while your data backend (SQL/ETL) keeps feeding the latest truth.

Scope

What kinds of data can D3 visualize?

Almost anything you can put into arrays, objects, and coordinates

Time Series
Regular or irregular timestamps: sales, sensor readings, web traffic, energy use. Patterns: line/area charts, multi‚Äëseries, rolling trends, calendar grids, anomaly markers.
Categorical & Numerical
Counts, rates, distributions, ranks. Patterns: bars, stacked bars, dot plots, box/violin, ridgelines, beeswarms.
Geospatial
Points, polygons, raster tiles. Patterns: choropleths, dot/heat maps, hex bins, flow maps, tiled/zoomable maps.
Networks & Hierarchies
Entities + relationships, taxonomies, org charts. Patterns: node‚Äëlink, chord diagrams, sankey, sunburst, treemap, edge bundling.
Text‚ÄëDerived
Token counts, topics, sentiment timelines. Patterns: annotated timelines, matrices, clustered scatter, word‚Äërelated layouts (when meaningful).
Event/Log Data
Clickstreams, operations, incidents. Patterns: timelines, swimlanes, calendar heatmaps, small‚Äëmultiples.

D3 is a low‚Äëlevel visualization toolkit: it binds data to DOM/SVG/Canvas and gives you fine control over scales, projections, transitions, and interaction. That flexibility makes it ideal for custom visuals and storytelling beyond template dashboards.

Fit

Who is D3 especially good for?

Teams that need custom visuals, high control, and narrative interaction

Businesses
  • Finance & Fintech: time‚Äëseries, risk, intraday views, order flow.
  • Retail & E‚Äëcommerce: funnels, cohorts, geospatial demand, product mix.
  • SaaS & Growth: activation, retention, A/B results, feature usage maps.
  • Operations & Supply Chain: SLAs, logistics flows, capacity calendars.
  • Energy & Utilities: load curves, outages, geospatial assets, ATES/UTES performance.
Expertise & Roles
  • Data Scientists / Analysts: bespoke analyses with statistical nuance.
  • Data/BI Engineers: custom front‚Äëends on top of lakes/warehouses.
  • Designers / Data Journalists: narrative, scrollytelling, explainers.
  • GIS / Earth Sciences: maps, cross‚Äësections, geology/groundwater models.
  • Research & Academia: experimental results, interactive figures.
Fields & Domains
